text:
Explore (Digging In)

Providing for Individual Needs

The Initial Challenge and What If...? Situation A give students the opportunity to scale the ratios of ages up and down, i.e., to rewrite using greater and lesser numbers. What If...? Situation B works using greater and lesser numbers. What If...? Situation B works backward by starting with a smoothie bar and asking students to find the children's ages.

As students work, listen for their ability to describe why their ratios are equivalent. (Language)

Suggested Questions

  • Would scaling up or down be helpful?
  • How do you know your ratios are equivalent?

Possible Correct Strategies

Using Pictures and Common Factors In What If...? Situation A, Jared's and Peter's ages are 10 and 15. These ages have a common factor of 5. We can use this common factor to notice that the ratio 2 to 3 is equivalent to the ratio 10 and 15 by making 2 groups of 5 from 10 and 3 groups of 5 from 15.

Scaling Up (as seen in Problem 2.1 What If...?)

Similarly, we can multiply 10 and 15 by any factor, e.g., 20 to 30 is equivalent to 10 and 15. In this case, each child gets twice as many pieces

To help students who may incorrectly think that "getting more pieces" means that the ratio is becoming more favorable, remind them that the ratio is the comparison between the numbers. In the case of Jared and Peter, Peter gets 1 1/2 times the segments that Jared gets.

Jared's 10 segments to Peter's 15 segments

2×↓ ↓×2

Jared's 20 segments to Peter's 30 segments

Possible Incorrect Strategies

Constant Difference Some students may see an additive relationship between the ages rather than a multiplicative relationship. Students using this reasoning might say that Jared should always get five segments less than Peter. They might say that Jared should get five segments and Peter should get 10 segments.

Suggest Question

  • If Peter is getting twice as many segments, he must be twice as old. Is Peter twice as old as Jared?

Identify which students have used the various correct strategies and the constant difference listed earlier so that you can bring them out in the Summarize. The Summarize should focus on equivalent ratios and on how these are like or unlike equivalent fractions. Because the connections between fractions and ratios can be confusing, it is good to focus students on the factor and multiple relationships between the two quantities in the ratio when you scale the ratio. It will be helpful to know which students can talk about these similarities and differences, as well as which students can contribute meaningful strategies for scaling the numbers in a ratio up or down.

Planning for the Summary

What evidence will you use in the summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? Question? What will you do if you do not have evidence>
